Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Scale of Governance in the Regulation of Land in Community Land Trusts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Addressing housing needs of all citizens and scientifically understanding the implications and impacts of various approaches to affordable housing provision provides a major challenge for urban policy. Community Land Trusts (CLTs) offer one strategy that is increasingly adopted in the housing policy realm. This project will address the question of how the geographical scale of a Community Land Trust affects its relationships in regional land and housing governance including interactions with other non-profit and government agencies, and its geographical identity. CLTs are private, not-for-profit organizations that own residential land in trust for a community, and are defined by membership and geographical boundaries at varying scales, from the sub-neighborhood to the urban region. CLTs offer long-term renewable leases for the use of their land to members, who in turn own the homes built on that land. A grassroots approach, CLTs initially developed in particular urban neighborhoods, but they are increasingly expanding their territories to cover large geographical areas, such as an entire city or county. Since CLTs are a potential and growing vehicle for supporting community-led redevelopment, their successes and failures have public policy implications. The project will offer insights about how CLTs relate to various levels of government as well as to their members, in geographically dispersed land trusts. Consequently, it will enhance understandings of urban development, community identity, and land regulation. The researchers will develop local and national advisory committees drawn from policy makers in CLTs and relevant government and non-profit institutions in order to drawn upon insights from, and disseminate research findings to, individuals and organizations working within and with housing-oriented community land trusts.

The project examines the importance of law and public policy in shaping land governance and the impacts on residents' perceptions of place and community. Through a combination of archival research, semi-structured interviews and roving interviews, the researchers will explore how community land trusts are structured legally, socially, and geographically. They examine the relationships of CLTs with members and non-members within the CLTs' territories as well as their relationships with local, regional, and federal governments. A case study of five CLTs within the Minneapolis - St. Paul metropolitan area allows for examination of the different ways that geography affects community identity and land use governance in CLTs, because the five CLTs vary in territorial extent. This comparison of neighborhood- and regional-scale impacts highlights the different ways that local and regional state institutions can engage with the project of CLT development with differential effects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project examined community land trusts (CLTS) in the Twin Cities, Minnesota metropolitan region (with comparative interviews in Duluth and Rochester, MN) by investigating the relationships between the geographic scale of a CLT, its engagement in regional land governance (including interactions with other non-profit and government agencies), and its geographical identity. Utilizing a qualitative research design, fieldwork was conducted during the summers of 2015 and 2016, which consisted of 124 semi-structured interviews with 112 participants, including: staff and board members of eight CLT organizations, homeowners from four CLT organizations, officials from major funding agencies which support CLTs in MN, and other relevant actors including lobbyist, realtors, and officials from mortgage lending agencies.  Alongside this data, archival research was conducted on all eight CLTs and participant observation was conducted at five CLT organization events.


CLTs work by owning land in perpetuity for the affordable use of low income people, who rent or buy residential housing on that land. CLTs can own land for many uses, including commercial space, playgrounds, community centers, parks, gardens, multi-family housing, and single-family homes. In Minnesota, CLTs most often work to create and preserve affordable single-family homes  They do this by separating ownership of land and housing; CLTs, in the form of a non-profit trust, lease the use of land to members, who in turn own the homes which stand upon that land. Since CLTs are a potential (and growing) model for supporting community-led redevelopment, their successes and failures have public policy implications. Although initially developed in particular urban neighborhoods, CLTs are increasingly expanding their service areas across larger geographical regions, such as entire cities or counties. CLTs uses existing legal frameworks to organize property and land ownership, but restructure land use governance by engaging with a different set of relationships for decision-making over land use when compared to conventional private property mechanisms.


This project produced three findings which have formed the basis for seven published (4), forthcoming (2) or in-review academic articles (2), one published editorial in an affordable housing practitioner journal, one article in press at a magazine for intentional communities, and multiple conference presentations and talks. Our first major finding is that community control within CLTs is limited by the terms of the CLT and the intentions of CLT funders, who most often prioritize particular uses of land oriented around affordable homeownership. Furthermore, CLTs rarely produce a coherent “CLT community” identity between residents; instead, participants more often thought of the CLT “community” as the CLT staff who direct organizational growth and health through the stewardship of properties. Still, one of our case studies, a CLT oriented around a defined neighborhood with a culturally-specific identity, was able and willing to be a vehicle for a neighborhood-based group’s vision for the preservation of affordable commercial space, cultivating more options for community control and geographically-based identity. Our second major finding was that the CLT ground-lease, which restricts any input on the uses of CLT land to the resident-occupier, effectively rules out alternative visions for creating community-defined land use. This finding is  important theoretically, as it points to the need for a refined conceptualization of property rights and their use in the CLT model. This finding also highlights the real limitations on how CLT organizations can use their property holdings. Our final finding was that the meanings of homeownership under the CLT model are similar to existing understandings of traditional homeownership. The important difference was that CLT homeowners see the benefit of CLT homeownership as being about securing autonomy and stability, rather than a financial return on their investment.


The broader impacts of this project are three-fold, with implications for policy, research, and pedagogy. First, understanding how CLTs function and engage with wider urban land governance has policy implications for governments and community development organizations. For example, groups looking to foster collective control of urban land might revise the typical CLT ground-lease to allow for more community-based uses of land and look for alternative strategies for financing CLT projects  Our in-depth qualitative data sets identify the challenges to the CLT model in the face of pressures to expand geographically, which is additionally helpful to CLT advocates and strategists nationally and internationally. In terms of research, our analysis and findings point to potential future avenues of research on the CLT model and other collective land ownership strategies regarding community identity formation, transformative subjectivities, and community control of land. Pedagogically, this project has direct implications for all PIs’ teaching and mentoring of graduate and undergraduate students. This included support for three individual graduate research assistants, which fostered learning in a collaborative setting. These experiences have enhanced their graduate educations and have led to developments in their own individual research projects.
